utterances: She's definitely there.
She's there and all her friends are there, too.
Well, I'll be in Vegas to see you.
Congratulations and I can't wait.
Thank you.
Thanks very much, Robby.
We're talking with Bette Midler and you're listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
Rosy's with us, Rosy calling from Wisconsin.
Hi, Ms. Midler.
I just wanted to say, of course we all know that you are a fabulous woman.
Congratulations on your show and all-success wish to you.
I wanted to also personally thank you for something I don't think people realize.
On the quieter side of your life, all of the restoration and garden work that you've done in New York City is an astounding - just an astounding thing.
And I personally want to say thank you so much for your commitment to that program.
Thank you so much.
It's the part of my life that I like the best.
It's - I've had this organization, New York Restoration Project, since 1995, and we've restored a lot of public parks.
We have taken ownership of 57 community gardens which we restore.
And we restore three or four of them every single year with the help of a lot of great donors like Home Depot and Toyota and Target.
And we are planting a million trees.
In the next ten years, our organization, along with a number of other greening organizations in New York City, will be planting a million trees in line with Mayor Bloomberg's PLANYC initiative.
And we are - this year we have planted almost 80,000 and we have another 20,000 to go in the fall.
So we're doing great, and everyone - the outpouring of support has been sensational.
And it's a kind of a legacy, and I'm really - I never expected it to become so important, to consume so much of my life.
But I enjoy it so much, and I enjoy the fact that people enjoy it.
I get a lot of support and a lot of gratitude for it.
You do and you're an extraordinary, extraordinary person and I just think it's nice that people know you're a very multi-faceted and busy woman to do all those things.
Thank you.
And we really appreciate it.
Thank you so much.
Thanks, Rosy.
Let's see if we can go now to Sarah, Sarah calling from Cleveland.
Hello, Ms. Midler.
Hello.
Hi.
You know, I was just calling in, just mostly out of gratitude for your incredible career.
I'm 27 years old and I don't remember a time in my life without the presence of you.
Oh, that's so nice.
Thank you.
And your work has definitely transcended generations.

And it amazes me how completely poignant and relevant it always is, even down to the commentary made in a song such as ""Lullaby in Blue,"" which brings to light the important issues embedded within adoption.
You spoke about the understated position of a birth parent.
Just the comments you've made about how AIDS has decimated the population of your friends.
Although you are an amazing performer, your voice is just something that needs to be heard, and I greatly appreciate that.
Although you broach very serious topics, you do it in a sensitive way, yet where it's not over-dramatic.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Gee, all this time I thought I was being overly dramatic.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But I appreciate it, thank you very much.
Thank you.
And thanks very much for the call, Sarah.
Is there something left that you would still like to do?
I think I'd like to finish the million trees.
That's a big deal.
That's going to be hard.
The mayor put aside 400 million dollars for this initiative over ten years, and I really would like to see that finished.
I think about all sorts of things.
You know, I live in New York City.
I've lived here on and off since 1965, and I've seen it go through highs and lows.

And I've seen, you know, Manhattan is one part of the city that's really - I can't say it's not thriving, I mean, real estate values are extraordinary and there's a lot of building and there's a lot of clamor for homes here.
But the outer boroughs, sometimes I think they've been neglected and so I'd like - I'd like to see it - I'd like to see the reforestation of New York City, I really would.
I think that's something that I've taken on and that's the main thing that I'd like to see done before I shuffle off this mortal coil.
Can you stay with us for a couple of more calls?
Yes.
All right.
Bette Midler will stay with us.
If you'd like to join the conversation, 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
Stay with us.
We're also going to be talking about the R.
Kelly trial when we come back.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is Talk of the Nation.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
And our guest today is Bette Midler.
She's got a new show in Las Vegas at the Coliseum at Caesar's Palace.
It's called ""The Showgirl Must Go On."" If you'd like to join us, 800-989-8255.
Email, talk@npr.org.
And I've read that you've told, quote, about your daughter, that if you ever enter into show business I'll never speak to you again.
How much of that was a joke and how much of that did you mean?
Well, I've gotten into hot water about that one.
I was very nervous about - actually, I said if you ever go into show business I'll kill you.
I didn't say I'll...
Ah.
Well, that's a way of not talking to her again.
Well, you know, I tell you.
I think I made a big mistake because that's really her own business.
It's up to her what she wants to do.
And she said to me, she told me that I had squashed whatever, you know, impulse she had had to be a performer.
And I really felt badly about that.
And so we talk about it every now and again, and I wouldn't be a bit surprised if she did wind up in show business.
I guess I wanted to save her the grief, you know, I didn't want her - I love her to death and I just didn't want her to be in any kind of psychic pain.
And it can be very painful.
It can be very hard.
It's - you know, the most marvelous part about the glamour of it and the photography and isn't it great, you get to wear good clothes and sit for two and a half hours in a makeup chair - fabulous.
All that part, the glamorous part is one thing, but the underbelly of it is quite stressful, and it can be quite unattractive.
And I just didn't feel like - I just didn't - I wanted to spare her that.
And so I made that comment, and she took it very much to heart.
But now we're rethinking, so...
Even at your level of success.

Because you don't, you know, I didn't want her to be compared to me, and I didn't want to have to say - to answer questions about me, and I didn't want her to have to, you know, be on a - have a yardstick and constantly be, you know, see where she is in comparison to me.
I didn't want that for her.
I felt that she - I wanted her to be her own person without any effect, without me having any effect on what she was or what she turned out to be.
And I don't think it's really possible, I really don't.

It's too - the machine is so big and this machine is very powerful, and the churning of the machine, the beast that has to be fed all the time, it's everywhere, you know, and now with the Internet it's - you know, it's beyond everywhere.
It's - you know, it's cosmic.
Nothing dies, either.
Nothing dies and it's there forever, and so I expect that she's going to be answering questions about me until she's, you know, an old lady.
And I don't look forward to that for her.
So I tried to, you know, I did the wrong thing.
I tend to step on my own feet, on my own tongue often, so I apologized and now we're - we talk about it.
We have our little summit conferences over the thing.
Let's speak with Laura, Laura's with us from Kansas City.
Hi, Ms. Midler, thank you so much for taking my call.
My pleasure.
Thank you.
I saw you just a couple of years ago on a talk show, which one I can't remember...
Me either!
You were talking about how decades were getting better, your 40th birthday, turning 50, and I wondered, is it still getting better?
Well, I'm going to call a dog a dog, and I'm going to tell you it is getting really hard.
My eyes are gone.

My eyes just sort of disappeared in the last couple of years, so now I have to wear glasses to read, which is my biggest heartbreak because I'm a big reader and I used to get into bed and read, you know, until all hours of the night.
And now I can't do that without a pair of glasses.
And, you know, I have little twinges here and there, and I kind of do see that it's tough.
It's really, you know, I'm out there with everybody else.
But I do try, and I'm a big believer in maintenance, big believer in exercise.
Big, big believer.
And I'm a big believer in Bragg's Apple Cider Vinegar with molasses and with, you know, with a chaser of fish oil.
I'm a big believer in this stuff, and it really has helped a lot.
I think you really do have to pay attention.
You can't just, you know, drop the ball and say, oh, the hell with it, I give up.
You can't really do that.
Otherwise, you'll - you know, things that you don't want to be visited by will definitely come up and visit you.
So I take the activist approach, and it has been good but I must say I do see, you know, I do see certain failings, and it gives one pause.
